data.title: The terminal header cuts the top of the console
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Fedora 24

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Use ZSH shell
2. Open a terminal by pressing " Ctrl + ` "

![screenshot from 2016-08-03 15-03-32](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13297000/17364921/c9bac34a-598b-11e6-8214-9adfb927f827.png)

data.title: CMD+D in new unsaved file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0-insiders
- OS Version: OSX

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Have 1 existing file open in VSCode
2. Click File/New (CMD+N) to create new unsaved file
3. Paste 

```
abc def
abc def
abc def
```
1. Put cursor inside `abc`
2. Hit `CMD+D` multiple times
3. Problem: Nothing gets selected

data.title: CMD+D and multicursor selection
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0-insiders
- OS Version: OSX

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create file with:

```
abc def
abc def
abc def
```
1. Put your cursor at `1,1` location
2. Hit `CMD+D` 3 times to select `abc`s
   ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1723815/17364000/ac28b700-594b-11e6-9574-ff73cc70a6ca.png)
3. Hit `right` 3 times to get into middle of `def`
4. Hit `CMD+D`
5. Problem: - It will select first def only - it should select all of them

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1723815/17364007/b28132d0-594b-11e6-83c8-575855dea351.png)

For comparison result of the same in Atom/Sublime:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1723815/17364041/d6595d9a-594b-11e6-8539-01911ea8a357.png)

1.3.1
- OS Version:

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a new file
2. Type 'hello'
3. Save the file
4. ctrl+tab to another tab
5. ctrl+tab back to the first tab
6. Try to undo

Result: undo is not working.

data.title: Can't drop or drag file[folder] on vscode -> open
Implement cursor move up/down by lines for cursorMove command
data.body: Current cursorMove command implementation only supports cursor move up/down by wrapped lines. To be complete, implement support for lines.

data.title: Extension API - How to log errors in extensions
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: OSx 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Code an extension :-)

I'm currently testing my extension locally before I want to publish it. Problem is, I can't possibly find all errors by myself. So I installed it on my friends computer as it would be installed through the marketplace.

Is there any possibility to `console.error` or anything similar from the extension? It seems there are no chances to log any errors other than the `showError` over the whole app.

I'm guessing this should be the Extensions tab in the output window?

Or is the only way to write down the errors in files?

Cheers
Chris

data.title: add `resolveWorkspaceSymbol`
data.body:
This PR allows `WorkspaceSymbolProviders` to skip the location (or parts of it) when searching for symbol. A new optional method (`resolveWorkspaceSymbol`) will be called when a match is selected and only then provider have to fill in remaining information. 

It will fix #890

data.title: Is there anyway to control the order of multiple CodeLens per line?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: `1.4.0-insider` e3758d2cdaae78082a08a45ae28ea1bed5f47e8c
- OS Version: `OS X El Capitan 10.11.6`

Steps to Reproduce:

Working on a PR for https://github.com/OmniSharp/omnisharp-vscode to add git CodeLens in addition to the references CodeLens. I've tried setting each (git vs references) as separate providers, and all in one provider, but since both types of CodeLens are asynchronously resolved the order of them is random -- as seen below:

![screen shot 2016-08-03 at 2 54 43 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/641685/17356491/bfd043fc-5925-11e6-9a31-7d0bbde83b53.png)

Is there any way to control the order of how multiple CodeLens will combine on a single line?

I should also mention that I tried changing the range associated with the CodeLens (one at the start of the line, the other at the end) but saw no difference either.

Any help would be greatly appreciated!

data.title: Window gets off screen when switching monitors
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1 (But occurred in earlier versions)
- OS Version: Windows 10.0.10586

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Start with the laptop like Surface 3 Pro, and connect a large size monitor. Keep the laptop screen as the Main Screen
2. Launch VS Code. Use the VS Code on the second monitor
3. Use it for a bit, then close it cleanly by exiting the app.
4. Make the attached monitor as "Make this my main display" from the Display settings (right click on the desktop).
5. Launch VS Code again.

You will sometimes see that the new window VS code generates is completely off screen.

Expected Behavior:

Make sure that the new  window will not go off-screen, but at least the top of the window to be visible on the visible area on either of the monitors so that I can click it and move it to the place I would like. 

Workaround:

Make the laptop screen the main screen, then re-launch the VS Code, or temporarily disconnect the other monitor.

data.title: Control+K twice can't kill the \n
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.1 (e6b4afa53e9c0f54edef1673de9001e9f0f547ae, 2016-07-12T13:31:10.994Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0

Steps to Reproduce:
1. `Control+a` jump to the beginning of line
2. `Control+k` kill the line
3. `Control+k` again to kill the new line character `\n`, **IT DOES NOT WORK**

`Control+k` it's the common behaviour in macOS just like emacs & shell, it works in most macOS applications.

data.title: ES6 code highlighting broken after "for of" with Map and destructuring
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.4.0-insider (e3758d2cdaae78082a08a45ae28ea1bed5f47e8c, 2016-07-29T18:41:58.915Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.10586

Steps to Reproduce:
1. type the following code

```
for( let [k, component] of this.components){
    let bounds = component.view.getBounds(); /// <= not highlighted, nor anything after this
}
```

![code-bug-example](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5633182/17349310/9de3c952-58ea-11e6-9007-ec3753ab04f4.png)
:  
Everything that follows is not highlighted...

The square brackets seem to be the problem; adding a semi-colon after fixes the highlighting (but of course is not valid code).

data.title: Go to column
data.body: It used to be that you could enter `2,3` in the Go To Line prompt to go to line 2, column 3. Apparently that isn't supported any more. We'd really like to have it using Monaco in F12. Is there any way to enable it?

data.title: File -> Open Recent menu shows paths containing "&" wrong
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.1 (e6b4afa53e9c0f54edef1673de9001e9f0f547ae, 2016-07-12T13:35:06.227Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.10586

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a directory with a & in the name, e.g. "C:\Test & Debug Directory", open the folder or a file in it in Visual Studio Code
2. In the menu File -> Open Recent you will see it as "C:\Test  Debug Directory" - without the "&"!

data.title: config.get does not return expected value if passing type argument
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Added a configuration option that's a boolean to my `packages.json`:

```
"configuration": {
    "type": "object",
    "title": "Dart Configuration",
    "properties": {
        "dart.setIndentSettings": {
            "type": "boolean",
            "default": true,
            "description": "Forces indenting with two spaces when Dart files are opened. This is on by default because VS Code doesn't support per-language settings and most people use tabs/4 spaces for other languages."
        }
    }
}
```

When I come to read it with `config.get<boolean>("setIndentSettings")` it comes back as undefined, yet `config.get("setIndentSettings")` returns false!

From my debug console:

```
$ config.get<boolean>("setIndentSettings")
  not available
$ config.get("setIndentSettings")
  false
$ typeof config.get("setIndentSettings")
  "boolean"
```

data.title: Include offset-len variant in text document content change events

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

I'm developing an extension which needs to send content changes to a separate service that is doing analysis. I'm using the `onDidChangeTextDocument` event.

Everything works fine if I'm only typing with one cursor; however if I use `Alt` to place multiple cursors, then I get the wrong offsets from `offsetAt` (presumably because it's using the new state of the document, not the one that the `Position` supplied was based on).

Example:

Create a file that contains two commented lines and no whitespace, but CrLfs:

```
//
//
```

Place your cursor on the end of the second line and type a character. You'll get an event saying the edit is on Line 1, Character 2 (this is correct, it's zero-based):

```
{"range":[{"line":1,"character":2},{"line":1,"character":2}],"rangeLength":0,"text":"a"},
```

If you feed this into `document.offsetAt` you will get back 6 (this is also correct; you have `SLASH` `SLASH` `CR` `LF` `SLASH` `SLASH` preceding it:

```
e.document.offsetAt(e.contentChanges[0].range.start) // 6
```

Now do the same thing, but with multiple edit cursors - one at the end of each line. You'll get an event for both lines at Character 2 (again, correct):

```
{"range":[{"line":1,"character":2},{"line":1,"character":2}],"rangeLength":0,"text":"a"},
{"range":[{"line":0,"character":2},{"line":0,"character":2}],"rangeLength":0,"text":"a"}
```

However, if you feed these into `document.offsetAt`, the first one (which is the change lower down the document) will return 7!

```
e.document.offsetAt(e.contentChanges[0].range.start) // 7
```

My guess is that it's because `offsetAt` is now seeing the `a` inserted on the first line, shifting the calculation.

Possible fix might be to provide the original document in the `TextDocumentChangeEvent`?
